properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring. A weak disturbance over central Yukon will create strong east winds of 60 km/h gusting 80 near the Richardson Mountains beginning this afternoon. These strong winds will persist tonight then ease Friday morning. Reduced visibility in blowing snow and cold wind chills down to minus 30 are expected. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-13T03:33:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-12T11:34:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1441779057.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will spread snow to the region by this evening and become heavy at times tonight and Friday morning. Temperatures will warm above freezing by Friday afternoon allowing the snow to become mixed with rain. Total snowfall amounts tonight through Friday morning are expected to be near 15 cm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-13T03:35:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-12T11:36:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1539023751.2020
Area: Boundary
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will move across the BC interior today through Friday. Light snow from the system will start this morning over Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass. The snow is expected to intensify tonight and persist through Friday. Total snow accumulations up to 40 cm can be expected before the snow tapers off to a few flurries Friday evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-13T03:38:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-12T11:39:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0479065780.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will spread snow at times heavy into the West Kootenay region tonight. The snow will persist through Friday morning and then become mixed with rain in the valley bottoms during the afternoon. General snowfall accumulations will be 15 to 20 cm with greater amounts expected over higher terrain. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-13T03:36:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-12T11:37:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1288004254.2020
Area: West Kootenay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will move across the BC interior today through Friday. Light snow from the system will start this afternoon over the Elk Valley region. The snow is expected to intensify overnight and persist through Friday. Total snow accumulations of 10 to 20 cm except 30 cm near Fernie can be expected before the snow tapers off to a few flurries Friday evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-13T03:39:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-12T11:40:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0431326882.2020
Area: Elk Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly 70 km/h, except 100 in the Canada Bay area. Time span: ending this afternoon. Remarks: A period of strong westerly winds is expected, with the highest gusts anticipated to occur in the Canada Bay area. Winds will gradually diminish this afternoon as they shift to the northwest. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-12T22:59:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-12T08:54:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4109616657.2020
Area: Northern Peninsula East
properties.Author: Environment Canada
